What happened is the RIS says that it's exactly $175, yet we heard Minister Watt in the chamber last week, when he was asked a question about this and he said: 'Oh, there was a bit of a mistake. It should haven't pointed out just that one source. It was multiple sources.' Minister Watt came in here and said that, to come up with that figure, they also used payscale.com and the AFR, who are a reputable organisation. They're the sources that they relied on to come up with the figure $175. Isn't it interesting that, when you go authentic.com.au, the exact figure that's on that website that Senator Cash was reading out before was exactly $175? Wow! What a crystal ball! Can someone get that crystal ball? Maybe you could use it to predict who's going to win the World Cup this year. Hopefully it will be Australia. That could be a chance with the way we're going so far. If it wasn't so ridiculous, then maybe we'd be having a serious think about this. This is absolutely crazy.

In my home state of Western Australia, 97 per cent of businesses are small businesses. They're going to be caught up with the impact of this bill. We senators from Western Australian have an arrangement. Senator Brockman and Senator Cash are here from Western Australia. We have what we call 'patron seats'. One of my patron seats is the seat of Tangney—a great part of Perth. There are 6,500 small businesses in the seat of Tangney. In places like Canning Vale and around Willetton—Senator Brockman knows these places—there are many, many small businesses. I bet the telephone has been running hot in the electorate of the member for Tangney. I bet that Mr Lim over there is being inundated with calls from businesses owners who are just trying to figure out what this is going to mean for their businesses. These are people that are busy just trying to keep their businesses afloat.

Anyone that's been involved in small business—and, for a short time, I ran my own small business; I ran it as a consultant—knows that it's tough. You've got to work out where the next pay cheque is coming from, where your next client is coming from and whether or not people going to pay on time. All of these factors are considered by a small business. You don't want to be also wondering whether you are going to get caught up in some industrial relations dispute with a bigger business. It might be a competitor in your industry. It might be a competitor that's under the same roof or in the shopping centre or the suburb that you're in—the 'common interest' or whatever it is.

Through the excellent questioning by Senator Cash last night and this morning, we're seeking to understand the guard rails to actually determine which businesses are going to be in and which businesses going to be out, what the definition is and who's going to be included. What we heard was just: 'Well, it's up to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission. We're going to leave it up to them.' What if you're the small business that's trying to determine how you're going to make this work? I've got no doubt that Mr Lim, the member for Tangney, will be inundated with people questioning him, but apparently this government thinks that there's no difference between a business that's got 20 people in it versus those that have 200 in it—or 21, even. There's a big difference, and, when you're trying to pull it together, it's tough going.

My daughter is 16. She's working casually for an employer in retail. She's got a regular pattern of work; she works every single Saturday. It's a great job that she's got. She's learning a lot in that job. She's getting experience. It's setting her up. When she finishes school next year and goes on to study, it will help her through her study. It's not a very big business to get lots of casuals in that sort of environment, particularly in a retail workplace. You might think, 'Twenty employees is a big business,' or 'Twenty employees is a big organisation.' Guess what? For those that are in that sort of sector, where you employ people for those shifts during the week, when there's a bit of a surge because it's a Saturday, and you want to have the headcount to be able to support the customers that are coming in there, you might hire those people just for that day. But you need them every Saturday so there's a regular pattern of work. Those businesses are going to be caught into this. Let me tell you: running a business like that is really tough. The last thing you want to be thinking about is whether or not you're going to get caught up in this union-attracting situation that's just about trying to get unions involved when you're just trying to run your business and make ends meet. When you're a small-business person, you're often the last person to get paid. You know that it's tough going. The problem is: this side over here, this lot over here, supported by—
Senator Chisholm: Also known as the government.

Senator O'SULLIVAN: The government of Australia, absolutely. I don't deny that. I don't know what you guys think. You think you're the masters of business, do you? Supported by the Greens, supported by Senator Pocock, this legislation is going to get through tonight, and Australians know, and particularly those in small businesses know, that they're the ones who will bear the cost of this.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Pratt ): I have to give the call to Senator—
An honourable senator interjecting—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: I've read the rules of the debate.
An honourable senator interjecting—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: It depends on what Senator Hanson-Young stands to do, according to the precedent here.
Senator Hanson-Young: I'm seeking the call.
Senator McKenzie: Point of order.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: What's your point of order, Senator McKenzie?
Senator McKenzie: There is an order of precedence and, as Leader of the National Party, I'm seeking the call.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Would the government like to seek the call? Senator McKenzie.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (21:16): Thank you so much. I rise to give my full support to this amendment. As I've said often in this chamber over the last 12 years, I had the great pleasure and misfortune of growing up in a small-business family. There was no Fair Work Commission looking after me as a 12-year-old on the back of my father's one-tonne truck, delivering milk around a small country town in the seventies and eighties. But I learned a lot from that experience—the importance of hard work, the stress of owning a small business, of being owner-operators and having everything on the line for the success of that small business, the stress of—
Senator Hanson-Young: It's your family. It's a cinch.

Senator McKENZIE: Senator Hanson-Young, I can talk for the full 10, or you can let me have my say, and you can do what you need to do tonight for this amendment. But, if senators here who will not support this amendment think that a small business with a 200 headcount on the books is somehow the fat cat, the big end of town, that again just shows the failed consultation process this government has gone through to bring us to this place tonight. Again, your own Minister for Small Business can't name one small business she's actually talked to. She's talked to a lot of unions. She's talked to a lot of organisers. She's talked to a lot of associations representing people, but has she bothered to even walk down her main street in Hobart and gone: 'Here I am. How are things going for you post COVID? How many people do you actually employ? Are you a big business? How will the decisions that we're putting before the Senate today impact your ability to grow and prosper and employ more people and pay them more money'?

The fact that this legislation before us is going to have businesses with 21 employees paying over $80,000 when they're forced into multi-employer bargaining is incredible. What margins do you think these families are on? We weren't the rich family in town. The newsagents aren't the rich family in town. The pharmacists are a bit richer, but they're not the huge fat cats that you're thinking they are. The fact that this Senate thinks that businesses that employ 21 people are the big end of town is quite incredible. It shows how out of touch you are.

It's not too late. I was really buoyed by Senator Birmingham's contribution. It is not too late for the Labor Party. It is not too late for the Greens, although, given who they represent in this place, they do represent the big end of town and the big unions. But, Senator Pocock, it's not too late to understand that small businesses are larger than 20 employees. The risks of this legislation and the unintended consequences, because Labor hasn't actually talked to anyone, are huge, particularly in the high inflationary environment we're in at the moment and the energy crisis that small businesses are facing. It means that people should remember the first principle of government, and it's actually to do your very best to do no harm. The fact you haven't consulted and the fact you have quite inner-city views on what constitutes a small business and what doesn't, and what level of impact they can actually bear, is quite incredible.
I know Senator O'Sullivan briefly touched on the spiritual healer's contribution to constructing the figures here before the chamber.
Senator Bilyk interjecting—

Senator McKENZIE: Yes, Senator Bilyk, the spiritual healers! I know you don't like to hear it, but the RIS was clear: it was disclosed by Senator Cash's forensic examination of this bill, in the short time we've had and the short Senate inquiry we had into the most radical industrial relations reform for decades, that it was actually a spiritual healer that informed the RIS.

I just find it quite depressing that you want to see the economy grow, you want to see workers paid more—we all do. But you don't do that by roping in small businesses with a head count of 21 to be coming up with a lazy $80,000, because it's just not there for them. It shows immaturity, naivety and a complete lack of engagement with millions of families around this country who actually run the joint, who have the guts to get up every morning and put the whole thing on the line—their house, their family's future—to run a small business. The entrepreneurial spirit that they display day in, day out is incredible.

I really recommend this amendment. It's a simple amendment. It adjusts the head count to a more appropriate level. There are multiple definitions that government uses on what defines a small business—21 ain't it! I recommend this amendment to the Senate.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Pratt ): Senator Hanson-Young.
Senator Henderson interjecting—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Senator Hanson-young has been waiting for the call. She's indicated twice.
Senator Henderson interjecting—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: I am quite happy to give you the call.

Senator Gallagher: I have a point of order on seeking guidance from the chair. It is normal practice that senators are usually called from each side of the chamber alternately. Senator Hanson-Young has indicated on three occasions that she would like the call, and it has stayed over this side of the chamber. My argument, Chair, is that it should alternate. That is the practice. It is explicitly identified in Odgers' in Chapter 10. The call should go to Senator Hanson-Young. This side of the chamber have had Senator Birmingham, Senator Cash, Senator McKenzie, Senator O'Sullivan and now Senator Henderson wants the call. That is hardly fair. That's five without going to this side of the chamber. The call should go to Senator Hanson-Young.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: What's your point of order, Senator Henderson?

Senator Henderson: On the point of order, I want to point out that I was on my feet first. If those rules operated, then the chamber would obviously be very dysfunctional with people putting their hand up well in advance when they wanted the call.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: That's what we have speaking lists for, as well, and we're in committee. Senator Hanson-Young, you have the call.
Senator HANSON-YOUNG (South Australia) (21:25): I move—

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Pratt ): I have a point of order over here. What is your point of order, Senator Brockman?

Senator Brockman: On the existing point of order: you are effectively ruling, here, that standing in the chamber is no longer relevant. Senator Hanson-Young was not on her feet. Senator Henderson and I were both on our feet. Senator Hanson-Young has flagged that she's about to shut down debate on an open-ended sitting. I would ask you—

The TEMPORARY CHAIR: I've listened to the points of order, and they're not valid points of order from the point of view that I am required to distribute the call fairly. Senator Hanson-Young had been seeking the call on three occasions. I ask senators to take their seat while I am speaking. Sit down while I'm speaking. It is my obligation to distribute the call fairly. I distributed the call to Senator O'Sullivan, previously, when it should have come to this side of the chamber at that point in time. Senator Hanson-Young did stand and seek the call at about the same time as Senator O'Sullivan. The previous Chair, Senator McLachlan, had advised me that Senator O'Sullivan was seeking the call, which is why I gave him the call without seeing Senator Hanson-Young. Frankly, on exactly that same basis, I can give the call to Senator Hanson-Young.
Opposition senators interjecting—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: I have ruled on the point of order and Senator Hanson-Young has the call.
Senator HANSON-YOUNG: I move:
That the question be now put.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: The question is that the question be put.

span.span: A division having been called and

p.span: Senator Brockman: Madam Chair, point of order.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: What is your point of order, Senator Brockman?
Senator Brockman: I ask for a written explanation from the President to the opposition on—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: I can give you another explanation now, which was that—
Senator Brockman: No, no—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: I gave Senator O'Sullivan the call based on him not jumping, based on the fact that the previous Chair had given me his name.

Senator Brockman: With due respect, I'm not dissenting from your ruling. I'm asking for a written explanation from the President to the opposition on that ruling and on whether that is consistent with past practice.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: I can advise that if there is anything inconsistent, you can be confident that the President will come back to the chamber.
The CHAIR: The question is that the question be put.
The CHAIR (21:36): The question before the chair is that amendments (17) to (20) on sheet 1779 be agreed to.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:38): I move opposition amendment (1) on sheet 1756:
(1) Schedule 1, item 463, page 137 (after line 15), at the end of section 65C, add:
(7) If the FWC makes an order under paragraph (1)(f), the employer may apply to the FWC to vary or revoke the order on the ground that:

(a) events or circumstances after the order was made demonstrate that the particular grounds on which the employer refused the request were in fact reasonable business grounds (disregarding paragraph (5)(a)); or
(b) due to a material change in circumstances after the order was made, it is now inappropriate for the employee's working arrangements to be such arrangements as are required by the order.
(8) An application under subsection (7) may be made at any time.
(a) the employer makes an application under subsection (7); and
(b) the FWC is satisfied that a ground mentioned in paragraph (7)(a) or (b) exists; and
(c) the FWC considers it is appropriate to vary or revoke the order to address the matter mentioned in that paragraph;
the FWC must vary or revoke the order accordingly.

(10) To avoid doubt, the requirements in subsections (2) and (2A) apply in the same way in relation to the varying of an order made under paragraph (1)(f) as they apply in relation to the making of such an order.

In speaking to this amendment, as Senator Birmingham has pointed out in relation to the previous amendments, multi-employer bargaining will go through the chamber tonight. This amendment will make it slightly better for the small businesses who are not exempt from this part of the act. The definition of small business that's been agreed to with Senator Pocock, which I don't agree with, is of 20 employees or under. They were exempt from the multi-employer bargaining part of the act—the single-interest stream expansion. They're not exempt from other changes in the act, and one of the other changes in the act is in relation to the rights for flexibility.

This amendment is all about ensuring that employers are not unfairly bound by a decision of the Fair Work Commission relating to workplace flexibility when the circumstances of their businesses change. Currently under the Fair Work Act, there are minimal ways for the Fair Work Commission to intervene in flexible work arrangements made under section 65 of the act. If COVID-19 has taught us a few things, what it has taught us in particular is that employers and employees are able to work with one another to ensure that they can properly put in place flexible working arrangements that suit both parties.

This all changes under the act, though, because the act now introduces a right to arbitration. What will now happen under the act is that, if the employer and the employee are unable to agree on a particular working arrangement, there will now be the right for the Fair Work Commission to intervene and arbitrate a decision on behalf of the employer and the employee. What is not provided for in the act is the ability of a business to request a review after a binding decision is made by the commission. What may well happen at the rate we're going—if you are seeing rising rates, if you are seeing rising inflation and if you are seeing electricity prices skyrocketing and getting out of control—is that the decision of the Fair Work Commission made in particular circumstances and then imposed on the business may no longer be fit for purpose in terms of the current circumstances.

All this amendment does, Senator Pocock—it's a very simple amendment—is actually ensure that there is a right for the business to request a review after a binding decision of the commission has been made. That's all it does. The amendment ensures that it becomes possible for a business to revisit a decision on flexible working arrangements. This will mean that, if a business suffers a change in circumstances—and businesses do suffer changes in circumstances—they will have access to a review of any determination made by the Fair Work Commission in relation to their business. This, I would put to the chamber, is abundantly fair, in particular for those smaller businesses who may have less ability to keep a flexible working arrangement because of the nature of their operations, particularly if their circumstances change. As I said, it is a very simple amendment. It doesn't take away what has passed through the Senate tonight. All it does is give businesses that ability to request a review after a binding decision is made by the commission to ensure that the terms and conditions that they work under continue to be fit for purpose for the business that they're in.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (21:42): I move:
That the question be now put.
The CHAIR: The question is that the question be put.
The CHAIR (21:51): The question before the chair is that amendment (1) on sheet 1756 be agreed to.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:53): I rise to move what I understand—unless the Jacqui Lambie Network make an appearance—to be the last amendments to be moved tonight. I seek leave to move opposition amendments (1) to (6) on sheet 1773 together.
Leave granted.
Senator CASH: I move opposition amendments (1) to (6) on sheet 1773:
(1) Schedule 1, item 629, page 217 (line 28), after "agreement", insert "(the relevant employers)".
(2) Schedule 1, item 629, page 218 (line 1), omit paragraph 216DC(3A)(b), substitute:
(b) whether the relevant employers are governed by a common regulatory regime;
(3) Schedule 1, item 629, page 218 (line 4), at the end of subsection 216DC(3A), add:
; (d) the history of bargaining of each of the relevant employers, including whether they have previously bargained together;
(e) the interests that the relevant employers have in common, and the extent to which those interests are relevant to whether they should be permitted to bargain together;
(f) whether it would be more appropriate for each of the relevant employers to make a separate enterprise agreement with its employees;
(g) the extent to which the relevant employers operate collaboratively rather than competitively;
(h) whether the relevant employers are substantially funded, directly or indirectly, by the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory;
(i) whether the relevant employers are of a similar size in terms of employees;
(j) any other matter the FWC considers relevant.
(4) Schedule 1, item 634A, page 223 (line 22), after "the employers", insert "(the relevant employers)".
(5) Schedule 1, item 634A, page 223 (line 30), omit paragraph 249(3A)(b), substitute:
(b) whether the relevant employers are governed by a common regulatory regime;
(6) Schedule 1, item 634A, page 223 (line 33), at the end of subsection 249(3A), add:
; (d) the history of bargaining of each of the relevant employers, including whether they have previously bargained together;
(e) the interests that the relevant employers have in common, and the extent to which those interests are relevant to whether they should be permitted to bargain together;
(f) whether it would be more appropriate for each of the relevant employers to make a separate enterprise agreement with its employees;
(g) the extent to which the relevant employers operate collaboratively rather than competitively;
(h) whether the relevant employers are substantially funded, directly or indirectly, by the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory;
(i) whether the relevant employers are of a similar size in terms of employees;
(j) any other matter the FWC considers relevant.

As Senator Birmingham has already stated tonight, multi-employer bargaining is going through tonight; it will shortly go through the Australian Senate. This amendment in some small way addresses the concerns that have been raised by business after business around Australia. It's in relation to the common interest test. When I've questioned the various ministers who've passed through the chamber during the committee stage of this bill, what I've been looking for by way of statutory interpretation going forward is some guidance in relation to what the common interest is.

The common interest, as we know, is based on three particular tests. It could be a geographic location or it could be a regulatory location—businesses in the same sector or industry. But in this legislation there is no other guidance given to the Fair Work Commission for determining what the common interest is.

For example, when we look at the geographical location, I put simple questions to the minister just to get some form of guidance for employers who may be compelled into multi-employer bargaining. If two businesses are in the same shopping centre, do they share the same geographical location? I would've thought I could get some type of indication, but the answer to the question was: 'That is for the Fair Work Commission to decide.' It's left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission, so, depending on the commissioner you get, I hope you don't end up getting different answers.

The next question I put to the minister was: 'Could a hardware store next to a hairdresser'—so they're right next door to each other in the shopping centre—'be compelled to bargain together under the geographical location common interest test?' Again, I would've thought there was a simple explanation: yes or no. That does fit within the geographical location test. But, again, the answer was: 'That is left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission.'

We then proceeded down a line of questioning in relation to distance. If two businesses are within one kilometre of each other, do they share a geographical location under the common interest test? Again, that is left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission.

Then there was this basic question: if we can't determine it, based on it being one kilometre or right next door to each other, is there a distance limit for the geographical location test? For example, do the employers need at least to be within the same suburb? Again, I would've thought, when asking for guidance in relation to a test, that that would be a pretty easy question and that, were you to pass it, you would actually leap over a hurdle and you would be one step closer to being compelled into multi-employer bargaining. But, again, the answer was: 'It is left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission.'

There was question after question after question. Could any two retail stores be considered as having the same nature, another part of the common interest test? The answer, you guessed it, was: 'It's left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission.' A butcher and a newsagency are both retail stores. Would they be considered as having the same nature? Again, it's left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission. Would two businesses in the mining sector be considered as having in the same nature, even if their activities are substantially different? I would've thought there would be a little bit of guidance, perhaps, in relation to that part of the common interest test but, again—there was certainly a theme going on in terms or all of the answers—that is left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission.

Again, all this amendment seeks to do is make clear that the factors which see employers bargain together are more clearly defined. That is all this amendment achieves. So, when the question of whether any two retail stores would be considered as having the same nature is posed—for example, would a butcher and a newsagency, which are both retail stores, be considered as being of the same nature?—there are actually a number of factors to the common interest test that the Fair Work Commission would have to take into account. All they are is the history of the bargaining of each of the relevant employers, including whether they've previously bargain together; the interests that the relevant employers have in common; the extent to which those interests are relevant to whether they should be permitted to bargain together; and whether it would be more appropriate for each of the relevant employers to make a separate enterprise agreement with its employees. All we're doing is providing some signposts for the commission in terms of undertaking what is, quite frankly, a decision that could, or could not, see a business in Australia with 21 or more employees roped into multi-employer bargaining.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (21:59): The government opposes these amendments. These laws are designed to give the Fair Work Commission a reasonable amount of discretion. The amendments proposed would add so much red tape that they would make the provisions impenetrable, which is perhaps the reason behind the amendments. This is what happened to the low-paid stream; there was so much red tape that no-one could get into it. There have been only four applications, and none since 2014.

This amendment is not going to fix our broken bargaining system by adding more and more criteria. We have designed these provisions to stop the race to the bottom on wages. We want to see businesses competing on quality, innovation and ideas; we do not want them to compete on wages. This is why we need to give the Fair Work Commission the discretion to decide for which employers it is appropriate to bargain together.

I've been listening here for hours tonight as senators have given their contributions. More broadly, the point behind this bill is Australians have been waiting for a decade to get wages moving. We have seen hour after hour in the committee stage of this debate the coalition refusing—and we know it was a deliberate design feature of their economic architecture—to support new regulation and legislation that will allow Australian workers to get reasonable wage outcomes, to fix a broken bargaining system, to put gender equality at the heart of our industrial relations legislation, to implement the Respect@Work report that the former government refused to act on and to place job security at the heart of the workplace relations system. The changes in legislation we are debating tonight will reinvigorate the bargaining system by making it easier for businesses and workers to reach agreement, with higher wages and productivity improvements. All of the international evidence shows that when you have effective bargaining arrangements in place supported by legislation, you will see the benefits flow through wages and productivity improvements, and that is the kind of economy we want to see working for Australian workers and for Australian businesses.

Only about 15 per cent of workers are covered by internal enterprise agreements at the moment. That has to change. That has to be a part of the story of why we have seen a decade of wage stagnation. We know it was part of the economic policy of the former government to make sure that wages were suppressed and that wage stagnation became a feature of our economic architecture. This government has made no secret. We made it very clear during the election campaign that we wanted to get wages moving, that we wanted to support minimum wage claims in particular, which we did. Do you remember the Prime Minister saying, 'Absolutely, I want to see wages moving.'? Absolutely. That is what the Australian people wanted to see, because our agenda was endorsed in May.

Once elected, we changed the submission going to the Fair Work Commission on the minimum wage case. When those opposite were in government they had a whole section about the importance of low-paid jobs, a whole section. Year after year they would submit to be Fair Work Commission: have a look at the minimum wage case but there are some really good arguments for why you keep wages low. We on this side have a different view to that. We are ensuring that we are creating an industrial relations system that works for business, works for those low-paid workers in industries where bargaining has failed them—those feminised industries and the care economy that is going to be so important to the strength of our economy in years to come. We know the services sector is going to be a key part of the jobs growth of the future and we have to make sure we are dealing with the wages and conditions in those sectors. It is no good to have all of those workers suffering under poor wage outcomes and poor conditions. That is the point of this bill. The reason why we have sat here for hours on end debating this, arguing for this, with us on this side supporting it, challenging your arguments and disagreeing with them, is because this is exactly the legislation that Australia needs to make sure that working people get appropriate remuneration and recognition for the work they do and that businesses can thrive and innovate, and productivity can be part of the economic conversation once again.
Senator WONG (South Australia—Minister for Foreign Affairs and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (22:04): I move:
That the question be now put.
The CHAIR: The question is that the question be put.
The CHAIR (22:11): The question now is that amendments (1) to (6) on sheet 1773 be agreed to.
The CHAIR (22:15): I intend to put the final question, unless any other member has a contribution. No? The question now is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

BILLS
Broadcasting Services Amendment (Community Radio) Bill 2022
First Reading
Bill received from the House of Representatives.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:30): I move:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:30): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

The Broadcasting Services Amendment (Community Radio) Bill 2022 (the Bill) will provide greater certainty and clarity for community broadcasting licensing processes. It will support listener access to high quality and diverse community radio services as well as provide regulatory flexibility for the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).

Every week, more than 5 million listeners tune-in to more than 450 community-owned and operated radio stations around the country. This includes 1.4 million listeners from non-English speaking backgrounds, listening to broadcasts in more than 100 languages.

The community broadcasting sector exists at the heart of local communities by broadcasting local news, telling local stories, and providing a platform for local voices and music that is essential to a well-informed and inclusive society.

The first measure in the Bill will amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (the Act) and clarify that the renewal process for community radio licences is not a competitive process. While this has always been the policy intent of the Act, it has not been explicitly stated. This measure clarifies that, when the ACMA is considering a renewal application, it will only consider the current radio service and not a proposed new radio service.

With this amendment, the Government is providing greater security and certainty to existing licensees. This will ensure existing community radio broadcasters can plan for future programming and infrastructure needs with greater certainty. However, this amendment is not intended to affect the ACMA's ability to refuse to renew a licence if it is found the current licensee is not providing a radio service that meets general community needs. As such, Australians will continue to have access to quality radio programming that reflects their interests.

The second measure clarifies the ACMA's powers to allocate new community broadcasting licences and temporary community broadcasting licences with effect from a specified future date. Currently, prospective radio stations do not have advance notice to set up broadcast infrastructure and station programming. This has meant that successful community radio licensees have sometimes taken significant time to begin their broadcasting service following the initial allocation of their licence.

This amendment will allow the ACMA to provide licensees with advance dates for the commencement of services. It will contribute to the streamlining of spectrum planning and give prospective stations the time needed to plan and make necessary preparations to have the best possible circumstances under which to begin broadcasting.

The third measure clarifies the matters the ACMA may consider when allocating a new temporary community broadcasting licence. The intent of the temporary licensing regime remains unchanged, and that is to give aspiring broadcasters access to spectrum in a fair and effective manner. However, the amendment gives the ACMA the flexibility to ascertain if a temporary licensee is not providing a quality service. The Government considers this will help ensure the integrity and reputation of the community radio sector is maintained. Consequently, it should minimise the risk of poor-quality services to listeners or services that don't meet the needs of the local community.
The fourth measure will give the ACMA the discretion to limit the number of temporary community broadcasting licensees that can share a particular frequency.

It has always been the policy intent of the Act to enable temporary licensees to share frequencies to assist with the sustainability of the community broadcasting sector and effective management of spectrum. However, this amendment is designed to maintain the integrity and reputation of the community broadcasting sector by giving the ACMA the flexibility to decide if a limit on a particular frequency is necessary.

The fifth measure will include deadlines by which late applications to the community broadcasting licensing process can be made. This will assist with timely processing of late applications, giving both the broadcasting applicants and the ACMA clarity about the process while safeguarding against the unintended expiry of licences. In turn, this will prevent any unnecessary disruption of radio services.

The final measure clarifies the community broadcasting licence allocation process. Currently, the ACMA has an implicit power to decide to commence a process to allocate one or more community broadcast licences, after which it must advertise for applications for those licences. The existence of an express power more clearly enables the ACMA to delegate the decision to commence the process to allocate a community broadcast licence. These amendments do not change the current arrangements in regards to the requirement to advertise for applicants, or decisions to allocate a community broadcasting licence to a particular applicant.

The Government is committed to supporting the long-term sustainability of the community broadcasting sector. This is evidenced by the additional $4 million per year of ongoing funding the Government is providing for the Community Broadcasting Program from 2023-24. This takes annual funding for the program to over $20 million per year.

This Bill is a further step to provide certainty for community broadcasters and provide listeners around Australia with continued access to high quality and locally relevant news, information and content.
Senator HENDERSON (Victoria) (22:31): I commend this bill to the Senate.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:31): I also commend this bill to the Senate, and I thank the Senate for their support.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Third Reading

The PRESIDENT (22:31): As no amendments to the bill have been circulated, I shall call the minister to move the third reading unless any senator requires that the bill be considered in Committee of the Whole.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:31): I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Animal Health Australia and Plant Health Australia Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 2022

p.span: Animal Health Australia and Plant Health Australia Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 2022
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Third Reading

The PRESIDENT (22:32): As no amendments to the bill have been circulated, I shall call the minister to move the third reading unless any senator requires that the bill be considered in Committee of the Whole.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:32): I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
The PRESIDENT: Senators, we shall now deal with the Financial Sector Reform Bill 2022, in accordance with the order agreed to—
Senator McKenzie: I have the second reading speech for the Animal Health Australia and Plant Health Australia Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 2022, and I was standing.
The PRESIDENT: Sorry, Senator McKenzie—
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator McKenzie: I was standing. Senator Hanson-Young will confirm I was standing on my feet when you read that bill out. You didn't look up, and I was standing.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Hanson-Young?
Senator Hanson-Young: Thank you, Madam President. I did see—
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator Hanson-Young: I'm being very gracious.
An honourable senator: You are!

Senator Hanson-Young: I did see Senator McKenzie on her feet. However, I do think it was at the wrong point. However, earlier in this fortnight we gave leave for a member to incorporate their second reading speech out of that session, and I suggest we do the same thing for Senator McKenzie.
The PRESIDENT: Senator McKenzie, the suggestion's been made that your speech is incorporated.
Senator McKenzie: Chair, I rose when the Clerk read out the bill, and I would like to make my contribution.
Senator Ruston: Can I just seek some clarification about what's actually going on?
The PRESIDENT: Senator Ruston, Senator McKenzie has raised a point of order: that she was on—
Senator Ruston: No, sorry. What was the bill?
The PRESIDENT: Oh, sorry. The Animal Health Australia and Plant Health Australia Funding Legislation Amendment Bill. We've just done the third reading.
Senator Ruston: I was just checking whether we did a second reading on it. I heard you read out the title of the bill. Didn't we skip the second reading?
Senator McKenzie: I'll incorporate it. I'm going to have to review, because I had advice that we were up to the second reading, which is why I jumped when I did, Chair.

The PRESIDENT: Senator McKenzie, we've had a very long day, and we've had long sittings this week. If we've made a mistake then I apologise. We're all doing our best. The offer's been made for you to incorporate the speech, and you've indicated you're happy with that.
Senator McKenzie: Well, if that's the only opportunity, I'll take that opportunity.
The PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator McKenzie.
Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (22:36): I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
Maintaining Australia's strong biosecurity status ensures our food security and protects agricultural trade.
This can only be achieved through a strong government-industry partnership.
One of the many ways this partnership takes effect is through the work of Animal Health Australia and Plant Health Australia.

Through these bodies, the Australian Government partners with state and territory governments and a number of livestock and plant industry bodies to further our shared biosecurity interests and ensure Australia's world class produce remains in high demand.
Incursions of exotic animal diseases or plant pests into Australia are relatively rare, but they do have serious potential impacts.
Detections of foot and mouth disease and lumpy skin disease in one of our nearest neighbouring nations has had the government and livestock industries on high alert.
The government has taken immediate action to prevent these diseases from entering Australia, implementing the strongest biosecurity response in our nation's history.

This includes our three-pronged approach of supporting Indonesia's response to both diseases with animal vaccinations and technical support, stronger measures at the border and increased preparedness here at home.
Because, the risk of incursion cannot be entirely mitigated.
This is why governments and industry bodies partner as signatories to the Emergency Animal Disease Response Agreement and Emergency Plant Pest Response Deed.

If the worst should happen and an exotic animal disease or plant pest should make its way into Australia, emergency eradication responses are mounted and cost-shared under these deeds to give the best possible chance of eradication.
Government and industry investment can avoid significant pest or disease management cost to our producers in the long run.
Over the past few years, under these emergency response arrangements, we have been able to eradicate citrus canker and three strains of avian influenza.
Varroa jacobsoni—a bee parasite—was also eradicated and we are now working to achieve the same outcome for its more problematic cousin, varroa destructor.
Four kinds of biosecurity levies provide an equitable way for all producers to contribute to the cost of the biosecurity activities and eradication responses that benefit their industry.
Animal Health Australia and Plant Health Australia levies fund activities such as biosecurity education, planning and surveillance, as well as AHA and PHA membership.
Emergency Animal Disease Response and Emergency Plant Pest Response levies primarily fund industry contributions to eradication responses.
They can also be spent on other biosecurity activities once these financial obligations are met.
An issue for Plant Health Australia member industries is that for the EPPR levy this alternative use is limited to purposes related to emergency plant pests under the plant response deed.
Increasing the flexibility in how these levies can be spent to include all plant health and biosecurity activities will increase their effectiveness.
The Bill will achieve this by broadening the range of permissible uses for these levies.
Plant industries have welcomed this change, as it will allow them to focus available funds on their industry's most pressing biosecurity needs, whether for exotic or established plant pests.
However, meeting response costs remains crucial—it is the main purpose for emergency response levies—and the Bill will not change that.
This Bill will also modernise and streamline the AHA and PHA funding legislation, including by removing redundant or duplicative provisions.

For example, a complex provision for funding biosecurity-related research and development activities through PHA levies will be removed in favour of using PHA's more straightforward industry planning processes.
The Bill will also simplify the process by which the relevant PHA industry member for a specific biosecurity levy is determined.
This will reduce regulatory and administrative burden.
Honey bees provide valuable pollination services to a myriad of plant industries and the honey industry's biosecurity activities are now characterised as plant biosecurity.
Therefore, references to honey in the AHA Act can now be removed.
The Bill will also allow the AHA Act to facilitate the levy arrangements that are likely to be needed if other response deeds are agreed.
Each of these changes will make the AHA and PHA funding legislation more effective, efficient and fit for purpose.
This will strengthen the ability of industries to invest meaningfully in biosecurity and help maintain Australia's enviable position as a world-class agricultural producer and exporter.
Financial Sector Reform Bill 2022
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Senator RUSTON (South Australia—Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate) (22:36): Could I seek the guidance of the chamber: I would like to seek leave to make a very short contribution in relation to the Financial Sector Reform Bill 2022, which is subject to the order that was agreed to on the motion of Senator Gallagher. I'm just wondering if I would be able to seek leave to make a short statement before we move into that.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:36): On that, as I understand it, the motion passed by the Senate earlier today has this bill subject to a guillotine, so there's a series of questions that are just being put, and it doesn't allow for contributions on the bill.
Senator RUSTON (South Australia—Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate) (22:36): I was seeking leave to make a short contribution before we move into that guillotine order. That was all.
The PRESIDENT: Leave is granted for one minute.

Senator RUSTON: The coalition will not stand in the way of the Financial Sector Reform Bill 2022 passing. However, we have to note for the record our deep concerns about the process around the bill. For the second week in a row, we've seen the government fly a kite on finalising the legislation to implement the recommendations of the financial services royal commission. As yet, for the second week in the row, we have seen a mad scramble, a deal with the Greens and a failure to deliver certainty to our financial institutions. Tonight the government are gutting their own bill. This is a broken promise from the government that promised to be collaborative, promised to be pro-business and promised to provide stability.

We still have several unanswered questions to the government about the operation of this legislation. The inquiry into this bill acknowledged the potential consequences of the consumer credit reforms for small businesses in the sector and for low-income Australians' access to credit. It is critical that the government get the regulations associated with this bill right and not set protected earnings amounts that will leave businesses closing and consumers worse off in managing their financial affairs.
The PRESIDENT: We will now deal with the Financial Sector Reform Bill 2022. In accordance with the order agreed to earlier today, the question is that the bill be now read a second time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
The PRESIDENT: I will now deal with the amendments circulated by the government on sheets PM145 and PM146.
SHEET PM145
(1) Title, page 1 (lines 4 and 5), omit "to establish the financial services compensation scheme of last resort,".
(2) Clause 2, page 2 (table item 5), omit the table item.
(3) Schedule 3, page 43 (line 1) to page 73 (line 26), to be opposed.
SHEET PM146
(1) Title, page 1 (lines 1 to 4), omit "to deal with consequential amendments and transitional matters arising from the enactment of the Financial Accountability Regime Act 2022,".
(2) Clause 2, page 2 (table items 2 to 4), omit the table items.
(3) Schedule 1, page 4 (line 1) to page 23 (line 19), to be opposed.
(4) Schedule 2, page 24 (line 1) to page 42 (line 18), to be opposed.
The PRESIDENT: I understand the minister has documents to table.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:38): I table supplementary explanatory memoranda relating to the government amendments to the bill.
The PRESIDENT: The question is that schedules 1, 2 and 3 stand as printed.
Question negatived.
The PRESIDENT: The question now is that amendments (1) and (2) on sheet PM145 and amendments (1) and (2) on sheet PM146 be agreed to.
Question agreed to.
Third Reading
The PRESIDENT (22:39): The question now is that the remaining stages of the bill be agreed to and the bill be now passed with amendments to the title.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
BUSINESS
Days and Hours of Meeting

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Minister for the Public Service, Minister for Finance, Minister for Women, Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:40): I move:
That:

(a) the Senate, at its rising, adjourn till Monday, 6 February 2023, at 10 am, or such other time as may be fixed by the President or, in the event of the President being unavailable, by the Deputy President, and that the time of meeting so determined shall be notified to each senator; and
(b) leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the end of the sitting today to the day on which the Senate next meets.
Question agreed to.
